image.altText: optus 'yes' sign on glass fronted office block

items.synopsis: Optus says it is aware of an issue impacting mobile and internet customers, with services down since early this morning across the country.

title.children: Optus reports national outage affecting millions of customers

image.altText: Two women smiling while one cuts a red ribbon.

items.synopsis: According to the South Australian government, women aged 55 and over are one of the fastest growing populations who experience homelessness.

title.children: 'I can feel like a human again': Hopes new SA housing trial will divert women from homelessness

image.altText: Glenn Maxwell of Australia reacts during the ICC Men's Cricket World Cup.

items.synopsis: Glenn Maxwell — hampered with a bad back and crippling cramps — hits a stunning double century to guide Australia to victory over Afghanistan.

title.children: 'The greatest ODI innings ever': Hobbled Maxwell hits record double-ton in Aussie World Cup win

image.altText: A wide shot of a land with soldiers and tanks among destroyed buildings with a ferris wheel in the distance and ocean beyond.

items.synopsis: Israel says its forces are operating deep in Gaza City, adding that Hamas' most senior leader in the enclave is isolated in his bunker. Follow live.

title.children: IDF says troops move into 'the very heart of Gaza' as Israel marks one month since Hamas attacks

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The number of evacuees leaving the Gaza Strip through Egypt rose on Tuesday local time, a day after the Rafah border crossing was re-opened. At least 500 people, most of them foreigners or dual nationals and their dependents passed through Rafah, the only crossing that does not border Israel, Egyptian security sources said. Evacuations through the crossing were suspended on Saturday and Sunday after an Israeli strike on an ambulance that was heading to Rafah. Egyptian security sources said Egypt was continuing to press for increased aid and fuel into the strip and security for ambulances. Jordan's foreign ministry said 262 Jordanians were evacuated on Tuesday, out of a total of 569 that had been stuck in Gaza following the outbreak of fighting there. Canada said 59 of its citizens, permanent residents and family members were evacuated. Nineteen Gazans needing medical treatment were also allowed through, a medical source said, to join dozens of others who are being treated in Egyptian hospitals. Other countries with citizens cleared to leave on Tuesday included Romania, Germany, Moldova, Ukraine, the Philippines and France, according to the Gaza border authority. Reporting with Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Gaza evacuations through Rafah crossing accelerate after re-opening

children.content: The number of evacuees leaving the Gaza Strip through Egypt rose on Tuesday local time, a day after the Rafah border crossing was re-opened.
At least 500 people, most of them foreigners or dual nationals and their dependents passed through Rafah, the only crossing that does not border Israel, Egyptian security sources said.

props.alt: A toddler stands holding a kid's suitcase in between a bunch of luggage, a man kneels down towards a bag behind the child

children.content: Palestinians with foreign passports are waiting for permission to leave Gaza at the Rafah crossing.
(Reuters: Ibraheem Abu Mustafa)

Evacuations through the crossing were suspended on Saturday and Sunday after an Israeli strike on an ambulance that was heading to Rafah. Egyptian security sources said Egypt was continuing to press for increased aid and fuel into the strip and security for ambulances.
Jordan's foreign ministry said
262 Jordanians
were evacuated on Tuesday, out of a total of 569 that had been stuck in Gaza following the outbreak of fighting there.

props.alt: A man in doctor's scrubs holds the chin of a teenage girl, a woman sits on his other side holding a bag

children.content: A Palestinian doctor says goodbye to his family at Rafah, choosing to stay in Gaza to treat patients.
(Reuters: Ibraheem Abu Mustafa)
Canada
said
of its citizens, permanent residents and family members were evacuated.
Nineteen Gazans
needing medical treatment were also allowed through, a medical source said, to join dozens of others who are being treated in Egyptian hospitals.

props.alt: A woman holds a toddler in her lap, a young boy sits to her right and another woman to her left

children.content: A family waits at the Rafah crossing, where evacuations had been suspended due to an Israeli air strike on an ambulance.
(Reuters: Ibraheem Abu Mustafa)
Other countries with citizens cleared to leave on Tuesday included Romania, Germany, Moldova, Ukraine, the Philippines and France, according to the Gaza border authority.
Reporting with Reuters

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The United States would oppose a reoccupation of Gaza by Israel's military in post-conflict Gaza, the White House has said. White House national security spokesperson John Kirby told reporters that Israel and the US are friends and do not have to agree on every single issue. Israel has so far been vague about its long-term plans for Gaza if it defeats Hamas. In some of the first direct comments on the subject, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said Israel would seek to have security responsibility for Gaza "for an indefinite period". But officials said Israel is not interested in governing the enclave. Israeli Defence Minister Yoav Gallant said that after the war was finished, neither Israel nor Hamas would rule Gaza. Simcha Rothman, a politician in Netanyahu's religious-nationalist coalition, in a social media post called for "full Israeli control" of the strip. Israeli Foreign Minister Eli Cohen told the Wall Street Journal that Israel wants the territory to be under an international coalition, including the US, European Union and Muslim-majority countries, or administered by local Gaza political leaders. Israel pulled its troops and settlers from the Gaza Strip in 2005, and two years later Hamas took power there.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: US says it would oppose a reoccupation of Gaza

children.content: The United States would oppose a reoccupation of Gaza by Israel's military in post-conflict Gaza, the White House has said.
White House national security spokesperson John Kirby told reporters that Israel and the US are friends and do not have to agree on every single issue.
Israel has so far been vague about its long-term plans for Gaza if it defeats Hamas.
In some of the first direct comments on the subject,
Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said Israel would seek to have security responsibility for Gaza "for an indefinite period".
But officials said Israel is not interested in governing the enclave.
Israeli Defence Minister Yoav Gallant said that after the war was finished,
neither Israel nor Hamas would rule Gaza.
Simcha Rothman, a politician in Netanyahu's religious-nationalist coalition, in a social media post called for "full Israeli control" of the strip.

Israeli Foreign Minister Eli Cohen told the Wall Street Journal that Israel wants the territory to be under an international coalition, including the US, European Union and Muslim-majority countries, or administered by local Gaza political leaders.
Israel pulled its troops and settlers from the Gaza Strip in 2005, and two years later Hamas took power there.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: US news website Axios is reporting US President Joe Biden told Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in a call on Monday that a three-day fighting pause could help secure the release of some hostages, citing two US and Israeli officials. The US official reportedly said that under a proposal being discussed between the US, Israel and Qatar, Hamas would release 10-15 hostages and use the pause to verify the identities of all the hostages and deliver a list of names of the people it is holding. In a statement, the White House said Mr Biden and Mr Netanyahu discussed "the possibility of tactical pauses to provide civilians with opportunities to safely depart from areas of ongoing fighting, to ensure assistance is reaching civilians in need, and to enable potential hostage releases." It did not immediately respond to a request for comment on the Axios report.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Biden reportedly tells Netanyahu a three-day fighting pause could help release hostages

children.content: US news website Axios is reporting US President Joe Biden told Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in a call on Monday that a three-day fighting pause could help secure the release of some hostages, citing two US and Israeli officials.

The US official reportedly said that under a proposal being discussed between the US, Israel and Qatar, Hamas would release 10-15 hostages and use the pause to verify the identities of all the hostages and deliver a list of names of the people it is holding.
In a statement, the White House said
Mr Biden and Mr Netanyahu discussed "the possibility of tactical pauses
to provide civilians with opportunities to safely depart from areas of ongoing fighting, to ensure assistance is reaching civilians in need, and to enable potential hostage releases."
It did not immediately respond to a request for comment on the Axios report.

image.altText: A teddy bear surrounded by floral tributes left in a park

items.synopsis: Police have interviewed the driver at the centre of a tragic crash that killed five people in the regional Victorian town of Daylesford, but no charges have been laid.

title.children: Driver in Daylesford pub crash interviewed by police as investigation continues

image.altText: Front of a car crashed into a tree

image.altText: Benjamin Netanyahu in front of an Israeli flag

items.synopsis: For months Israel has been on the brink of a civil war, spurred by the government's plans to drastically change parts of Israeli life and society. And at the heart of it has been one man — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, writes Allyson Horn.

title.children: 'The real problem is the guy who's our leader': Israelis are furious with PM Benjamin Netanyahu

image.altText: Palestinians look for survivors following an Israeli airstrike in Khan Younis refugee camp.

items.synopsis: War began on October 7 when Hamas militants crossed from Gaza and killed 1,400 Israelis, mostly civilians, and abducted more than 200. Since then, Israel has bombarded the Hamas-run strip, killing more than 10,000 people, around 40 per cent of them children, according to regional health officials.

title.children: Israel's war with Hamas enters its second month

image.altText: Front on view of an icebreaker ship.

items.synopsis: Officials at the Australian Antarctic Division were left scrambling after a decision to block RSV Nuyina from transiting the Tasman Bridge and refuelling close to port, with the true cost of a 660km detour now revealed.

title.children: What should have been a 4km refuelling trip for Australia's icebreaker is now a 660km debacle

image.altText: Casuarina Prison drone

items.synopsis: The ABC reveals more details about the conduct of a senior officer on duty the night 16-year-old Cleveland Dodd was found unresponsive in his cell at Unit 18. Warning: This story discusses incidents of self-harm and contains the images of an Indigenous person who has died.

title.children: Senior officer was lying down, partially undressed, in dark office on night Cleveland Dodd found unresponsive

title.children: Wall Street up, ASX digests rate hike and potential of another

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: I have taken over the blog for this morning, because Dan is doing a story on the business fallout from the Optus outage. With mobile phones, landlines and a lot of payment systems out due to the telco's network outage, there's no doubt it will cost many millions of dollars. Are you a business owner or someone else who has lost money because you can't use your phone, internet or payment system? Do you normally work from home, but can't log-in because you're an Optus customer? Get in touch via the comments. If you'd be happy to do an interview on camera then please include some contact details that will work (an email address perhaps, if your phone is out) or drop Dan an email directly, ziffer.daniel@abc.net.au, but only if you are willing to speak to him on camera .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Are you an Optus customer who runs a business? We want to hear from you

children.content: I have taken over the blog for this morning, because Dan is doing a story on the business fallout from the Optus outage.
With mobile phones, landlines and a lot of payment systems out due to the telco's network outage, there's no doubt it will cost many millions of dollars.
Are you a business owner or someone else who has lost money because you can't use your phone, internet or payment system?
Do you normally work from home, but can't log-in because you're an Optus customer?
Get in touch via the comments.
If you'd be happy to do an interview on camera
then please include some contact details that will work (an email address perhaps, if your phone is out) or drop Dan an email directly, ziffer.daniel@abc.net.au, but
only if you are willing to speak to him on camera

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Well, OK, it's been 13 rate increases overall. But it looks like, after a four-month break, there's a good chance that the Reserve Bank is hoping it's one and done with yesterday's resumption of rate rises. That's the analysis from Westpac's new chief economist Luci Ellis, who was until last month the assistant governor (economic) at the RBA. "We do not expect that the RBA will follow up with another rate increase in December. "The last paragraph of the statement contained a shift in language from 'Some further tightening of monetary policy may be required' used in the October media release to 'Whether further tightening of monetary policy is required'. "This reads as the Board hoping not to have to raise rates again, but being very willing to do so if things change." NAB's Alan Oster, now the longest standing big bank chief economist in the game, disagrees. "Reflecting recent data, the staff's inflation outlook has been revised up and we now see one further rise as likely to balance the risks, pencilling in a 4.6% rate peak in February, though December is live," wrote NAB's economics team. "Looking further ahead, given the resilience of the economy and labour market thus far, we now see rate cuts as unlikely to begin until November (previously August) with gradual cuts through 2025 and early 2026 to 3.1%, around the long-run neutral level." Personally, I quite like Peter Martin's analysis, published on the ABC News website this morning. With consumption and inflation still clearly trending down, and wages growth likely to have peaked below 4% per annum in the September quarter (ABS data out next week), I'm not sure the RBA even needed this rate hike.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: One and done for the Reserve Bank?

featuredLink.title: Australia is the odd one out on interest rates around the world

children.content: Well, OK, it's been 13 rate increases overall. But it looks like, after a four-month break, there's a good chance that the Reserve Bank is hoping it's one and done with yesterday's resumption of rate rises.
That's the analysis from Westpac's new chief economist Luci Ellis, who was until last month the assistant governor (economic) at the RBA.
"We do not expect that the RBA will follow up with another rate increase in December.

"The last paragraph of the statement contained a shift in language from 'Some further tightening of monetary policy may be required' used in the October media release to 'Whether further tightening of monetary policy is required'.
"This reads as the Board hoping not to have to raise rates again, but being very willing to do so if things change."
NAB's Alan Oster, now the longest standing big bank chief economist in the game, disagrees.

"Reflecting recent data, the staff's inflation outlook has been revised up and we now see one further rise as likely to balance the risks, pencilling in a 4.6% rate peak in February, though December is live," wrote NAB's economics team.

"Looking further ahead, given the resilience of the economy and labour market thus far, we now see rate cuts as unlikely to begin until November (previously August) with gradual cuts through 2025 and early 2026 to 3.1%, around the long-run neutral level."
Personally, I quite like Peter Martin's analysis, published on the ABC News website this morning.

With consumption and inflation still clearly trending down, and wages growth likely to have peaked below 4% per annum in the September quarter (ABS data out next week), I'm not sure the RBA even needed this rate hike.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Yep, there was a rate hike yesterday. But don't think that's the end of it. Daniel Ziffer here, from the ABC business team — with you for the morning. The decision by the Reserve Bank to lift the key "cash rate" continues to reverberate — and there's the potential for another hike before Christmas as the central bank continues to fight inflation, which is currently running at +5.4% annually. The ASX futures index has it down a point to 6,989. It'll open at 10am AEDT. On US indices, the blue chip Dow Jones index of mega-companies was up +0.17%, the broader S & P 500 was +0.41% higher and the tech-loaded Nasdaq lifted +1.15%. More rate reaction all day as well as the release of one of the mot important economic and social indicators of all: life expectancy data. However you get started for the day, enjoy it!
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Wall Street up, Australian markets to digest rate hike

children.content: Yep, there was a rate hike yesterday.
But don't think that's the end of it.
Daniel Ziffer here, from the ABC business team — with you for the morning.
The decision by the
Reserve Bank

to lift the key "cash rate" continues to reverberate — and there's the potential for another hike before Christmas as the central bank continues to fight inflation, which is currently running at +5.4% annually.
The
ASX futures
index has it down a point to 6,989. It'll open at 10am AEDT.
On US indices, the blue chip
Dow Jones
index of mega-companies was up +0.17%, the broader S
P 500 was +0.41% higher and the tech-loaded
Nasdaq
lifted +1.15%.
More rate reaction all day as well as the release of one of the mot important economic and social indicators of all: life expectancy data.
However you get started for the day, enjoy it!

image.altText: a skyline with houses

items.synopsis: There's nothing in the RBA governor's statement to suggest she is thinking of pushing up rates again, and financial markets are also betting this rate hike will be the last, writes Peter Martin.

title.children: Australia is the odd one out on interest rates around the world

image.altText: A smiling family of five stand around a table with cakes on it.

items.synopsis: Lisa Mammone and her husband do all they can for their kids, but they are bracing to make even more sacrifices as interest rates hit a 12-year high.

title.children: The Mammones live from one payday to the next. The RBA rate rise will mean saying 'no' to their kids more

image.altText: A police officer's vest with taser.

items.synopsis: Two South Australian police officers have been removed from operational duty after they allegedly used a taser during the arrest of a man at a care facility.

title.children: Police officers under investigation after taser, pepper spray used in arrest of man

image.altText: Jason De Ieso was murdered in late 2012

items.synopsis: All seven men found guilty of murdering Adelaide man Jason De Ieso have now filed notice to appeal against their convictions.

title.children: Seventh man found guilty of murder of Jason De Ieso to appeal

image.altText: A woman with blonde hair and a white shirt looking angry.

items.synopsis: A 48-year-old woman accused of operating a puppy farm in Adelaide's north while on a good behaviour bond over previous animal cruelty offences will contest the new charges, a court has heard.

title.children: Convicted puppy farmer denies new charges after RSPCA seizes 86 dogs

image.altText: A storm cloud building over trees and paddocks

items.synopsis: Some of the storm activity has the potential to become severe, carrying the risk of gusty winds, heavy rain and hail.

title.children: After the driest September-October on record, much of Australia to cop severe thunderstorm activity

image.altText: Clare stands outside wearing a bright red blazer.

items.synopsis: Clare is autistic and was struggling to fit in at school, but when life went online in the pandemic, things improved. Experts say she's not alone.

title.children: Clare used to worry she was 'too much'. When school went online, things got better

image.altText: People holding up phones and taking photos of Albanese.

items.synopsis: The Chinese media's coverage of Prime Minister Anthony Albanese's visit to China this week has generally been positive, with experts saying it reflects Beijing's changing approach to the relationship.

title.children: China's media had criticised Australia for years. So how has it covered the prime minister's long-awaited visit?

image.altText: A woman in a peach coloured hospital gown holds three white pills in her left hand

items.synopsis: Antibiotics have been around for less than a century. But as resistant bacteria become increasingly difficult to treat, we risk a greater number of deaths from infections.

title.children: What would a world without life-saving antibiotics look like?

image.altText: Georgina Ker looks pensive as she hugs her 15-year-old daughter.

items.synopsis: With her son missing weeks of school at a time, Georgina Ker followed the "tough love" prescription she was told would remedy her son's "behaviour problem". A new survey has found more than one-in-three parents have reported school refusal with their children in the past year.

title.children: First data on school refusal trend suggests 'shocking' problem is much bigger than first thought

image.altText: Sign in red dirt reading Arnhem Space Centre.

items.synopsis: The fledgling Arnhem Space Centre in the remote Northern Territory is looking to substantially expand its facilities and launch capacity if it's given the tick of approval.

title.children: One launch a week, 14 launch pads: Massive expansion pegged for remote Australian rocket base

image.altText: Silhouette of man and child with southern lights

items.synopsis: An aurora australis visible to the naked eye has been seen across Western Australia in the brightest display of southern lights in years.

title.children: Aurora australis 'brighter than in Antarctica' seen across WA

image.altText: Venus appears as a yellowed marble, cracks run across its face

items.synopsis: Researchers have made the first direct detection of atomic oxygen in the atmosphere of Venus. Some say it builds the case the planet was more hospitable in the past.

title.children: Oxygen detection in Venus' atmosphere points to a very different past

image.altText: Two silver towers are engulfed in flames and smoke, with a bridge in the foreground

items.synopsis: The Hamas-led attack on October 7 was the latest in a long line of historic intelligence failures.

title.children: 'Talk about irony and insanity': How some of history's biggest intelligence failures have led to disaster

image.altText: A composite image of two women in black face veils

items.synopsis: When the Pakistani government abruptly announced all foreigners illegally living in the country had to leave, hundreds of thousands of Afghans packed up and headed to the border. But these two women decided to stay, fearing they would be worse off if they returned to their homeland.

title.children: A vengeful ex, arrest or worse: These women say only horror awaits them if they're forced into Afghanistan

image.altText: A young woman climbs into a cabin on a large machine

items.synopsis: Vanessa Grady studied to become a dental nurse, but now she drives machinery for an industry ready to embrace women's contribution to construction.

title.children: From holding a stop sign to driving trucks, women play important role in industry's future

image.altText: snorkellers holding placards underwater.

items.synopsis: Ocean scientists say fossil fuel use needs to stop if ecosystems such as the Great Barrier Reef are to have a fighting chance of survival.

title.children: Scientists' clarion call on fossil fuel projects as oceans warm faster than predicted

image.altText: A view from a high building shows a large, snowed-in basketball arena below, minus its roof.

items.synopsis: It is the second fatal gym collapse in the Chinese province in just a few months, after 11 people were killed when a school gym was destroyed in July.

title.children: Basketball gym collapses in China's Heilongjiang province, killing three and injuring one

image.altText: A headshot of a woman with dark rimmed glasses

items.synopsis: Rhonda O'Sign previously pleaded guilty to stealing from Little Athletics Tasmania's fundraising account to go shopping. She also admitted she rigged a raffle to win a Thermomix food processor.

title.children: Woman who rigged raffles, stole charity money raised by Little Athletics kids avoids jail

image.altText: people in masks perform on top of a snow covered building, right image is a selfie of person in delivery driver uniform

items.synopsis: Just hours after Russia's invasion of Ukraine, Lucy Shtein knew it was time to escape. If she ever returns, a Moscow court says, she faces immediate arrest.

title.children: Pussy Riot member Lucy Shtein fled Russia dressed as a delivery driver — she's now on an international wanted list
